titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.29 Richmond, Va. Tuesday, February 3, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter cents per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: The fight at Blackwater.
div3.p:
The fight at Blackwater between the Federate numbering.
It is stated, from ten to fifteen thousand, and the Confederates, under Gen. Fryor, commenced Saturday morning about dawn, our pickets being suddenly driven in, and the enemy shelling our camp by the light of its fires.
Captain Cort's (S. C.) battery and a section of Captain Wrights battery replied to the fire.
After the artillery duel was over, the fight was maintained about one hour with musketry, when the enemy ceased firing and retired.
Gen. Pryor fell back eight miles to Carrsville.
Our loss was not over fifty killed and wounded. Among the killed was Col. Poage, of Pulaski county, commanding the 54th Virginia, and Capt. Dobbins, of the 17th Virginia. Col. P. was struck in the thigh by a fragment of shall, and bled to death in a few minutes.
In Wright's battery Capt. Wright, Lieut. Watkin and private George R. Watts, of Halifax, were slightly wounded.
From the following dispatch, received from Petersburg last night, it will be seen that the enemy suffered severely:

Petersburg, Feb. 2.--Reliable intelligible from Suffolk, Saturday, states that General Corcoran, not General Peek, commanded.
The enemy admit a loss in killed and wounded of 530.
Among the killed is a Lieutenant Colonel, name not recollected, and Captain Taylor. General Gibbs was severely wounded.
All the hospitals in Suffolk were filled with wounded, and the Baptist Church was seized for a hospital.

div3.head: Tragedy in Farmville.
div3.p:
The quiet town of Farmville was shocked on Thursday last by a tragedy in its streets.
R. B. Staples, of Amherst county, Va., was shot dead about 1 o'clock on the day named by Lieut. Col, Henley, of the 51st Virginia regiment, also of Amherst.
It appears that Col. H., who is a husband, had been informed that Staples had boasted of having dishonored him, and proceeded to Farmville Wednesday for the purpose of taking his life.
The next day he met B. in the street, and fired on him, three shots entering his body and one piercing his heart, killing him instantly.
Col. H. then surrendered himself into the hands of the authorities, and will be tried at the next session of the Prince Edward County Court.
Both parties to this fatal affair were respected citizens of Amherst, Staples was engaged in one of the Government stores at Farmville.

div4.p: Senate.--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock by Mr. Hunter, and opened with prayer by Rev. Andrew Broaddes, of the Baptist Church.

Mr. Sparrow, of Louisiana, from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported been the House bills, one to repeal certain clauses of an act entitled "an act to exempt certain persons from military service, &c." and the other to modify "an act to exempt certain persons from military service, &c." and resolutions on the same subject; and, also, an original bill from the committee on the same subject.
The bill "to provide further for the public defence" was read three times and referred to the Committee on Military Affairs.
Mr. Burnett, of Ky., and Mr. Johnson, of Ga., were each granted leave of absence for a week.
The bill reported by Mr. Hill, of Ga., allowing each head of the principal Departments of the Government to seats upon the floor of the Senate and House was amended and laid on the table.

Mr. Brown, of Miss., submitted a bill to fill Executive and Judicial offices with persons not liable to military duty.
[The bill provides that it shall be the duty of the Secretary of War, after the passage of the act, to cause all white persons between 18 and 45 years, now in Government employ, not in the army or navy, to be forth with enrolled as conscripts unless this has previously been done, and cause the places now filled by them to be rapidly filled by competent persons not now liable to military duty.
It is made the duty of all officers of the Government to supply the places of all such persons in their employ with competent persons not liable and immediately thereafter to report the name of the person whose office or place has been thus supplied to the Secretary of War; and, on receiving such report, it shall be the duty of the said Secretary to cause such person to be assigned for duty to some regiment then in the field.] Read and laid on the table.

The unfinished business, viz., the bill for organizing the Supreme Court of the Confederate States, coming up, Mr. Henry, of Tenn., addressed the Senate in an able argument in opposition to the pending motion, which was to strike out the 45th and 46th sections of the bill.
He was followed by Mr. Haynes, of Tenn., who advocated the motion.
Pending discussion, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --The House met at 12 o'clock and was opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. Brown.
On motion of Mr. Holes embe, of Va., the bill on impressments, introduced by him some days since, was taken up and made the special order for Thursday next.

Mr. Kenner, of La., from the Committee of Ways and Means, introduced a bill making appropriations for the support of the Government from February 1st to June 30th, 1863. The bill was ordered to be printed, and made the order of the day for to-morrow during the morning hour, and from day to day till disposed of.

Mr. Conrad of La., introduced a joint resolution to provide a homestead for the officers and privates of the Confederate army.
Referred to a special committee to consist of one from each State.
Mr. Chilton, of Ala., offered resolutions upon the same subject, which was referred to the same committee.

Mr. Perkins, of La., offered a resolution that the Committee of Ways and Means be instructed to report on that portion of the President's Message which recommends that indemnity be provided for those whose property has been destroyed by order of the Government.
Agreed to.

Mr. Barksdale, of Miss., offered a resolution that the President be requested to furnish this House, if not incompatible with the public interest with copies of all the letters and telegrams of Major-General Levell to the War Department in reference to the defences of New Orleans, from the 25th of October, 1861, to the date of the surrender of that city.
Mr. Davis, of Miss., offered as a substitute for the above the following:
Resolved, That a committee of five be appointed to inquire into the causes of the fail of New Orleans, and assistain if any person is blamable for it; and if so, whom.
These resolutions elicited considerable discussion, participated in by Messrs. Barksdale, Davis, and Conrad.
Mr. Dargan, of Ala., moved to lay the resolutions on the table, upon which Mr. Conrad called the ayes and noes, which were ordered, with the following result: Ayes 37; noes 48.

On motion of Mr. Royston, of Ark., the subject was laid over and the House resolved itself into Committee of the Whole, (Mr. Curry in the chair,) for the consideration of the special order, being the bill to declare what persons shall be exempt from enrollment for military service.

Mr. Clopton of Ala., offered an amendment, to come in after the word "States," in the sixth line of the original bill, as follows--"and except these ministers of religion who are authorized to preach in accordance with the rules of their ts and are in the regular discharge of their ministerial duties."This amendment was adopted — ayes 36, noes 29.

Mr. Wright, of Ga., offered the following, to come in immediately after the amendment above: "And except officers who have resigned or who shall hereafter resign, on account of wounds received in the service of their country." Not agreed to.
Mr. Russell, of Va., offered the annexed amendment, which was agreed to--"and except such State troops as are now exempt by law from military service." Agreed to.
Mr. Chilton, of Ala., moved to amend the amendment of Mr. Russell by adding the following words--"so long as they remain in such State service." This was also agreed to.

Mr. Heinkell, of Tenn., moved further to amend by adding the following--"and such officers of the several States comprising the Confederacy, as are not by the laws of such States subject to military service in time of war." Agreed to.
The question then came up upon the substitute of Mr. Collier, of Va., for the bill reported from the Military Committee, which is as follows:

The Congress of the Confederate States of America do enact. That all white persons who shall be held unfit for military service in the field, by reason of bodily or mental incapacity, or imbecility, under rules to be prescribed by the Secretary of War; the Vice President of the Confederate States, the officers, Judicial and Executive of the Confederate and State Governments, including postmasters pointed by the President and confined by the Senate, and such clerks in their offices as are allowed by the Postmaster General, and now employed, and excluding all other postmasters, their assistants and clerks; and except such State officers as the several States may have declared, or may hereafter declare, liable to militia duty, the members of both Houses of the Congress of the Confederate State and of the Legislatures of the several States and their respective officer; all clerks now in the offices of the Confederate and State Governments authorized by law, receiving relative or fees; all votes at our troops heretofore raised by any State since the passing of the act for neither to provide for the public defense," approved April 16th 1862, while such troops shall be in active service under State authority, Provided That this exemption shall not apply to any person who was liable to be called into service by virtue of said act of April 16th, 1863; all pilots and persons engaged in the merchant marine service; the president, superintendents conductors, treasurer chief clerk, engineers, managers, station agents, section masters two expert track hands to each addition of eight miles, and mechanics in the active service and employment of railroad companies, not to embrace laborers, porters, and messengers the president, general superintendent and operators of telegraph companies, the local superintendent and operators of said companies not to exceed four in number at any locality but that at the seat of Government of the Confederate States; the president, superintendents, captains, engineers, chief clerk and mechanics in the active service and employment of all companies engaged in river and can at navigation, and all captains of boats and engineers therein employed; one editor of each newspaper now being published, and such employees as the editor or proprietor may certify on each to be indispensable for conducting the publication; the public printer and those employed to perform the public printing for the Confederate and State Governments; every minister of religion authorized to preach according the rules of his sect and in the regular discharge of ministerial duties; and all persons who have been, and now are members of the Society of Friends, and the Association of Dunkards, Hezarenes and Mennohis's in regular membership in their respective denominations: Provided, Members of the Society of Friends, Hezarenes, Mennonists and Dunkards shall furnish substitutes or pay a tax of $500 each into the public treasury; all physicians who now are, and have been for the last five years, in actual practice of their profession; all superintendents of public hospitals, lunatic asylums, and the regular physicians, unless and attendants therein, and the teachers employed in the institutions for the duty, dumb and blind; in each apothecary store, now established and doing business one apothecary in good standing who is a practical apothecary; all superintendents, managers, mechanics and fulness employed in the productional all persons engaged in burning cake, smoking and manufacture of iron, regular miners in coal mines, and all colliers engaged in making charcoal for making bar and pig iron, not to embrace laborers, messengers, wagoners and servant, unless employed at works conducted under the authority, and by the officers or agents of a State or in works employed in the production of iron for the Confederate States; also a regiment raised under, and by authority of the State of Texas for iron for defence, now in the service of State who in such service; Provided, further, that the exemptions above and granted hereby, shall only continue while; the persons exempted are actually engaged in their respective pursuits or occupations; Provided, further, that the Secretary of War shall, upon terms and conditions as may be prescribed by him, and with the approval of the President, exempt from all Military service, or for specified purposes, such person or persons, as, with the approval of the President, he may deem essential for the good of the service, or the general interest of the country; and Provided, further, That the enrollment of persons between forty and forty five-years of age, shall be suspended until the President shall call such persons into the military service.
Sec. 2.--All acts or parts of acts, heretofore passed in conflict with the provisions herein contained, are hereby repealed.

Mr. Curry, of Ala., (Mr. Wilcox of Texas, in the chair,) moved to strike out in the 59th line of the substitute the following words: "All colliers engaged in making charcoal for making bar and pig iron" This amendment was agreed to.
Mr. Strickland, of Ga., moved to insert after the word "mines," in the 58th line of the substitute, the word, "and one chief collier." This was also agreed to.

Mr. Hilton, of Fla., moved to amend the substitute by striking out the words, "the president, superintendents, conductors, treasurer, chief clerk, engineers, managers, station agents, section masters, two expert track hands to each section of eight miles, and mechanics in the active service and employment of railroad companies, not to embrace laborers, porters, and messengers."
Mr. Hilton, at the suggestion of Mr. Ralis, so modified his amendment as to exclude engineers from its operation.

Mr. Smith of N. C., offered the following amendment to the preposition of Mr. Hilton, which was accepted: "Upon the payment annually into the Confederate Treasury by such companies of the sum of $500 for each engineer so exempted, during the period of his exemption."

On this proposition the ayes and noes were called by Mr. Lyons, and the vote resulted: Ayes, 38, noes 34.
So the amendment was agreed to.
Mr. Holt, of Ga. moved to amend by striking out the entire substitute of Mr. Collier, and offered a long substitute, which he discussed at considerable length.
After some further discussion the Committee rose, and the House adjourned.

div3.head: General Assembly of Virginia.
div3.p:
The Senate met at 12 o'clock, and was called to order by the Lieutenant Governor.
Prayer by Rev. Dr. J. C. McCabe.
A communication was received from Mr. Douglas, apologizing for non-attendance, on account of severe illness in his family.
A bill declaring in what cases Senators and Delegates in the General Assembly shall continue in their respective capacities until their successors are duly elected and qualified.
A bill authorizing the sale of the Roanoke Valley Railroad was passed.
A bill for the relief of Gen. Alfred Heckley was passed.
House bill to incorporate the Prospect Ten-Yard Company, in the county of Prince Edward, was passed.

Resolutions of Inquiry.--By Mr. Frezler: That the Governor be requested to transmit to the Senate copies of any contracts that have been made under his authority with proprietors of iron works for the hire of negro for the current year.
By Mr. Marshall: That the committee inquire into the expediency of amending certain section of the Code, so as to appoint two commissioners of election instead of five etc. By Mr. Alderson: On exempting all owners of slaves in the State from taxes upon such slaves as have fled to the public enemy, and all property seized and carried away by the said enemy.
By Mr. Branch: Condemning any guarantee of the Confederate war debt by the State--laid upon the table.
By Mr. Whittle: That the Committee of Courts of Justice inquire into the expediency of repealing certain portions of the Code of 1880, as authorizes aliens to hold lands situated within the Commonwealth.
A message was received from the House announcing their disagreement to the amendments of the Senate bill in relation to exempts and asked the appointment of a conference, which was acquiesced in.
And then, on motion of Mr. Brannon, at 2 o'clock P. M., the Senate adjourned.
House of Delegates.--The House assembled at the usual hour, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Read of the Presbyterian Church.

On motion of Mr. Mallory, Senate bill No. 18 amending the 12th section of the 20th chapter of the Code so as to compensate the Public Printer for printing and binding the journal of the senate at its extra session, was taken up and voted upon, as follows: Ayes 15, noes 68.
Mr. Jones moved — a reconsideration of the bill upon the ground that it was evident the House did not understand its merits.
The motion carried, and, upon the further motion of Mr. Jones, the bill was committed to the Committee on Finance.

The following resolution of inquiry was introduced by Mr. Anderson, of Rockbridge: Into the expediency of employing deserters from the Yankee army on the public works, under the superintendence of a competent Confederate officer, instead of negro slaves now so employed, without sending them out to seek employment in the country, and ascertain whether some arrangement cannot be made with the Confederate Government to that effect.
Agreed to.
Mr. Bouldin moved to take up the bill passed by the House some days since, exempting from military service persons who have furnished substitutes for the war.
[This bill was amended by the Senate making them liable to service for a period of sixty days--to which the House refused to concur and from which the Senate refused to recede.]

The bill having been taken up and the House insisting upon the original bill, Mr. Bouldin moved the appointment of a committee to confer with the Senate on the subject of disagreement, which was agreed to, and the committee designated by the Speaker.
The order of the day — the bill for the suppression of extension — was called for when.
Mr. Robinson, of Richmond city, addressed the House at considerable length in opposition to the bill.
He was followed by Mr. Anderson, of Botetourt, who occupied the time until ½ o'clock in defence of the bill.
On motion of Mr. Bass the further consideration of the subject was postponed until 12½ o'clock tomorrow.
On motion of Mr. Lyon the House adjourned.

div3.head: A Magnificent present.
div3.p: --The New York Herald thus describes a residence which has just been presented to Mrs. Gen. McClellan by her husband's friends:

The house is not only delightfully situated, but it has been provided with all the essentials to comfort and even of fashionable elegance.
The have been most exquisitely While the are covered with the rich carpets of Turkey, the capacious collars are with ...

We are indebted to the courtesy of Captain Philip Cashmayer for New York papers of Saturday last, the 31st ult. Gold opened on Friday at 155 and closed at 155 ½ Exchange closed at 171½ Cotton opened at 86 and closed at 93.
The New York Herald says that 75,000 of Gen. Lee's troops have been withdrawn and sent to North Carolina. Gen. McClellan went from New York to Boston Wednesday.
At all the railroad stations, if the Herald telegrams are to be believed, there was an ovation.
The same paper thinks the Army of the Potomac will again come to grief if McClellan is not immediately put in command.
Burnside and his wife reached New York Tuesday night. A most affecting interview took place between McClellan and himself.
After these two matchines military chieftries had condoled with one another the crowd rushed in, and so great was the pressure that Mrs. Burnside fled to her chamber.
Burnside's shoulders being broad he stood his ground and submitted to the hand-thanking with remarkable coolness and nonchalance:

div4.head: From the Army of the Potomac.--Opening address of fighting Joe Hooker — Farewells of Franklin and Sumner.
div4.p:
Telegrams from the Army of the Potomac, dated the 30th, says that a heavy snow storm had rendered the roads about Falmouth impassable.
No movement has taken place in the army.
General Hooker has appointed his staff.
Gen. Butterfield formerly a Colonel, in the N. Y. State militia, is the chief.
The following is Hooker's address to his unhappy army:

head.hi:
Headquarters Army of the Potomac.
camp Near Falmouth,

div5.p: General Orders, No. 1--By direction of the President of the United States, the undersigned assumes command of the Army of the Potomac.
He enters upon the discharge of the duties imposed by this trust with a just appreciation of their responsibility.

Since the formation of this army, he has been identified with its history.
He has shared with you its glories and reverses with no other desire than that these relations might remain unchanged until its destiny should be accomplished.
In the record of your achievements there is much to be proud of, and, with the blessing of God, we will contribute something to the renown of our arms and the success of our cause.
To secure these ends your commander will require the cheerful and zealous co-operation of every officer and soldier in this army.
In equipment, intelligence and valor the enemy is our inferior.
Let us never hesitate to give him battle where over we can find him.
The undersigned only gives expression to the feelings of this army when he conveys to our late commander, Maj. Gen. Burnside, the most cordial good wishes for his future.
My Staff will be announced as soon as organized
div5.closer:
Joseph Hooker, Major Gen'l
Commanding Army of the Potomac.

div5.p:
The following is the farewell address of General Franklin, who is about to follow the fate of Fitz John Porter.
When the General came out from his quarters to proceed to the railroad station, he found assembled a cavalcade of two hundred of the officers of the division, who escorted him to the cars:

p.hi: To the Officers and Men of the Left Grand Division:

div5.p:
In obedience to the order of the highest authority, the undersigned relinquishes the command of the Left Grand Division.
He does so with sincere regret.
His connection with the command has been over pleasant.
The prompt obedience and cheerful co-operation you have at all times rendered, your patient endurance upon the march, your steady bravery upon the field, the manly determination with which you have encountered and overcome the dangers and hardships of several trying campaigns command his admiration and gratitude.
All of you are endeared to him by gallant conduct and loyal service, and most of you by the memories of many battle fields, and the proud recollection that from none of them have you been driven back.
By these common memories he exhorts you to prove true, and fight gallantly in the future, as you have ever fought in the past, for the great cause in which you are engaged, believing that for yourselves you will win imperishable fame, for your country final and enduring victory.
In severing a connection which you have made so dear, he asks that no one will believe that he voluntarily parts with you in the face of the enemy.
div5.closer:
W. B. Franklin,
Major General Volunteers.
The following is the official order in regard to the recent changes in the Army of the Potomac:

div5.head:
Headquarters of the Army,
War Dept., Adj't General's office,
Washington, Jan. 28, 1863.
div5.p: 1. The President of the United States has directed:

list.item:
1st.
That Maj-Gen A. E. Burnside, at his own request, be relieved from the command of the Army of the Potomac.

2d.
That Major General R. V. Sumner, at his own request, be relieved from duty in the Army of the Potomac.

3d.
That Major-Gen W. B. Franklin be relieved from duty in the Army of the Potomac.

4th.
That Maj-Gen J. Hooker be assigned to the command of the Army of the Potomac.

div5.p: The officers relieved as above will report in person to the Adjutant General of the Army.
div5.closer:
By order of the Secretary of War.
E. D. Townsend,
Assistant Adjutant General.
The following farewell address of Gen. Sumner has been issued to the right grand division of the Army of the Potomac:

div5.head:
Hdq'rs right Grard Div'n,
camp near Falmouth, Va., Jan. 25, 1863.
div5.p: In pursuance with General Orders No. 20, from the Adjutant-General's office, War Department, Washington Jan. 26, 1863. I announce to the right grand division that I have been relieved from duty in the Army of the Potomac by order of the President of the United States.

I have only to recall to you the memory of the past, in which you have fought so many battles with credit and honor always, in which you have captured so many colors without losing a single gun or standard, and to urge that, keeping this re-collection in your hearts, you prove yourselves worthy of it. It is only in so doing that you can retain for yourselves a reputation well won, and which I feel will be preserved under the gallant, and sole commander, Major General Couch, to whom I confide you.

div4.head: The arrest of an editor in Philadelphia — Protest against it by the City Council--demand from the Legislature.
div4.p:
The City Council of Philadelphia took action on Friday evening last on the case of Mr. Bolleau, editor of the Evening Journal, who was sent to Fort McHenry by Lincoln's police for disloyalty.
The common branch of the Council adopted a resolution denouncing it as unjust and unconstitutional which was rejected by the select branch by one majority.
The following is an extract from the presentment of the Grand Jury in the case:

q.p: The testimony before the Grand Jury shows that the arrest was made by the order of General Schenck, for the publication of an editorial article, under the title of the "Message of Davis," and other articles of a like character, tending to the support and encouragement of the rebellion against the U. S. Government.

div4.p: After quoting the editorial alluded to by Gen. Schenck, the Grand Jury say:

q.p: They cannot refrain from saying that, whilst they indirectly, or as a body, could not conscientiously do anything which would have a tendency to weaken the General Government in the exercise of its constitutional authority for the suppression of this most wicked and causeless rebellion, yet they feel equally bound to enforce all laws that have for their object the protection of life, the security of property, and the liberty of the citizen, which laws are in their sacred keeping.

div4.p:
Judge Ludlow, of Philadelphia made the arrest the subject of a special charge to the Grand Jury.
He says "the time has arrived when we can no longer hold our peace; when the obligations imposed by of office compel us at every hazard to direct the Grand Jury to inquire into and determine by whose order and by what persons the arrest has been made."
In the Pennsylvania Legislature a resolution authorizing the Governor to go to Washington and demand release of the prisoner, was referred to the Committee on Federal Relations.

The New York World says that the country is indignant and shouted at the and tyrannical exercise of power.
The friends of the Constitution will henceforth resist all illegal encroachments on individual liberty and free discussion with the of conscious strength and the vigor and determination of men thoroughly in earnest.

div4.head: The War Feeling among the Senators and others in Washington.
div4.p: A Washington telegram, dated the 36th, in the New York Herald, says:

q.p:
Little expressions in the Senate debate on Thursday, on the subject of emancipation in Missouri, betrayed something like despair as to the result of the war. Sir.
spoke of the oceans of expenditure and Mr. Handerson insisted upon an immediate appropriation of twenty millions to abolish slavery in Missouri as a necessary condition precedent to her position as a Union State.
He looked upon emancipation as the best at this time of understanding billion, and a few millions in this way would effect more than a hundred million in blood At best there was doubt as to the success of our It was supposed that the policy of appropriating a handsome sum for emancipation in Missouri was a fixed thing in the Abolition programme, therefore people were surprised when Mr. as to the character of the resolution of Congress upon the matter.

div4.p:
His raising of the constitutional barrier was to avoid the responsibility before the people of appropriating a considerable sum of money for abolishing slavery in any State.
On this issue the radicals are sure to be cast on the rocks and to avoid Seylia he would fain run the risk of the of leaving Missouri to her fate.
Greeley's conversations here, and the drift of his editorials for letting the South go, have a strong effect upon the minds of the party.
They seem to be falling off from the war point a stitch at a time.
Pretty soon as things go on, they will strike out will, and finally get out of heart altogether.
It has come to light that Greeley is playing a big game to bring about intervention or recognition outside of his newspaper and his Washington hotel demonstrations.
He is writing letters to persons who are affiliated with the diplomats, and they inquiring of our officials who are charged with foreign subjects if he is playing this part upon Executive suggestion, and whether his position and influence in the country authorize him to break ground upon so grave a matter.

div4.head: The Saulsbury row.
div4.p: The Northern papers give the conversation that ensued in the U. S. Senate on the occasion of Senator Saulsbury's row. The bill up was that indemnifying the President for suspending the habeas corpus:
A long debate ensued on the bill in which Davis of Ky., Harris of N. Y., Powell of Ky., Doolittle of Wis, Harian of Iowa, Coliamer of Va., and Salsbury of Del., participated.

Mr. Saulsbury, of Delaware (Dam.) made a long speech and was called to order several times in the course thereof.
Finally when censuring the course of the President of the United States, calling him an imbecile, and calling him by name, the Vice-President called him to order, and requested the Senator to take his seat.
Mr. Saulsbury continuing his remarks the Vice-President said if the Senator did not take his coat he should order the Sergeant-at Arms to take him in charge.
Mr. Saulsbury.--Then the voice of freedom is not allowed in the American Senate.
The Vice-President.--The Sergeant at Arms will take the Senator in custody.

Mr. Saulsbury was thereupon taken out of the Senate displaying a revolver, which he took from his coat pocket.
After a short time Mr. Saulsbury came in the Senate again and began to speak.
Mr. Doolittle called him to order, on the ground that he had been called to order for contempt of the Senate, and could not be allowed to go on without leave of the Senate.
Mr. Saulsbury.--Does the Senator from say that I am in the contempt of any honorable man?
The Chair (Mr. Clark).--The Senator from Delaware will take his seat, as he is out of order.
Mr. Saulsbury.--Just as I please, or otherwise.
Cries of "Order."
The Chair.--The Senator will take his seat, and the Sergeant-at-Arms will take him in custody.
After further discussion, Mr. Saulsbury attempted to speak.
The Chair.--The Senator will take his seat.
Mr. Saulsbury.--No, sir!
Mr. Sumner rose to the question of order that the Senator from Delaware had been committed to the custody of the Sergeant-at-Arms, and he saw him on the floor.
The Chair said the Senator was in the custody of the Sergeant-at-Arms, and if he made further disturbance would be removed from the Senate.
Mr. Saulsbury took his seat, shaking his fist, and swearing at the Sergeant-at-Arms and Mr. Sumner.

div4.head: Another speech from Vallandigham.
div4.p:
The Northern papers contain a long and interesting account of a debate in the United States Congress between Vallandigham, Wright, and Bingham.
In the course of his remarks, Vallandigham said:

q.p:
You can never subdue the seceded States.
Two years of fearful experience have taught you that.--Why carry on the war?
If you persist, it can only end in final separation; believe it now, as you did not my former warnings, the whole Northwest will go with the South. Believe me, as you old not the solemn warnings of years past, the day which divides the North from the South the self same any decrees eternal divorces between the West and the East. There is not one drop of rain that falls over the whole vast expanse of the Northwest that does not find its home in the bosom of the Gulf. We must and will follow it with travel and trade; not by treaty, but by right; freely, peaceably, and without restriction or tribute, under the same Government and flag.

div4.head: The Yankee Army.
div4.p: Senator Rice, who is a member of the Military Committee of the Senate; made the following extraordinary statement in debate last week:

q.p:
"I do not believe there is a man in this Government in one of the departments to-day that can tell us whether we have five hundred thousand or a million of men in the field — not one who can come within fifty per cent of the number of sick and wounded in the hospitals, or with their regiments.
One department makes its estimate based on the supposition that we have one million two hundred thousand men in our army; another on the supposition that we have one million five hundred thousand men in our army.
The simple truth is that they do not know whether we have that number or half that number.
You may take the pay department, the commissary department, the medical department, the quartermaster's department, and you may take the commanding General and the Secretary of War, and you cannot, from all of them come within three hundred thousand or probably five hundred thousand of the number of men in the service; at least we cannot get the information."

bibl.n: a member of the Military Committee of the Senate

div4.head: The prisoners taken at Arkansas Post.
div4.p: A correspondent of the New York Times, writing from Cairo, Ill., January 22, says:

q.p:
The advance guard of the rebel prisoners lately captured at Arkansas Post, arrived here yesterday evening, including Gen. Churchill, the commander of all the defences of the Arkansas, and the line officers attached to the various regiments.
They came up on three steamers.
Gen. Churchill takes his captivity very coolly, chats fluently of the events through which he has lately passed and, in common with the other officers, attributes their final defeat and capture to the destructive effect of the gunboat fleet upon their fortifications which they had deemed almost impregnable.
Our heavy calibres, however, were too much for their casemates of oak and railroad iron, penetrating them like so much pasteboard.
Their gun were dismounted or broken by our accurate rifle practice, and the gunners killed by our shot and the flying splinters of wood and iron which were scattered in showers among the rebel troops inside the fort--Two feet of one rebel 9 inch casemate gun was knocked off by a 61-pound shot from one of the Union gunboats, but the enemy continued to load and fire the piece several times, even in its shattered condition.

bibl.n: a correspondent of the New York Times

div4.p: The rebel troops are in a very miserable condition for clothing, shoes, and blankets and must have suffered much during the eight days of cold weather that they have been on the Mississippi — They will be two days more in getting to St. Louis.

div4.head: The Career of the Florida--seven vessels destroyed.
div4.p:
The privateer Oreto ran the blockade of Mobile on the 13th ult., notwithstanding there were nine United States vessels-of-war stationed off the bar, and with full information that she was meditating an escape.
The steamers Cuyler and Oneida chased the Oreto, the latter of which had returned to the fleet off Mobile.
It is supposed that the Cuyler followed the Oneld to Havana, to which place it was thought that she would go. On her way to Havana she destroyed the brig Estella, of Boston.

On the afternoon of the 22d, four miles from the coast, the pirate fell in with the brig Windward, Capt. Robarts, from Matanzas, with a cargo of molasses for Portland.
The Windward was seized and burned, and the crew sent ashore in their own boat.
Her cargo belonged to Spanish merchants.
On the morning of the 23d, off Cardenas, the Oreto captured and burned the brig Cora Ann, of Mechies, Mc., Capt. Small, from Philadelphia, laden with shooks.
She was burnt only one mile from land and the Captain and crew sent into Cardenas in their own boat.
Soon after, the Oreto captured two more brigs, just out from Cardenas, burned one and sunk the other.
A schooner which arrived at Havana on the morning of the 24th states that the Oreto was last seen with the British flag flying, steering for the Bahamas.

A letter from Havana, dated 24th January, says:-- "Nothing is talked of here but the atrocities committed by the rebel pirate Mafflit.
The Florida has captured and destroyed four American vessels with valuable cargoes. "

The Florida was pursued after leaving Mobile by the Federal steamer Cuyler. Capt. Mafflit hauled to and gave her a shot cutting away the forewent.
The Cuyler was so disabled that she had to sents pursuit.

The World says that the exploits of the Florida caused profound excitement in New York.
Thursday, and well they might as she is as swift as the Alabama, stronger, and carries heavier The Florida is commanded by an officer who believes in fighting.

div4.head: The extraordinary price of cotton.
div4.p: The New York Herald, of Saturday, in an editorial on the cotton market, says:

q.p:
This article has reached a price in the New York market which it never bore before since it has been known as a staple.
Day before yesterday it suddenly jumped to 89 cents to the forenoon, and in the afternoon sales were reported at the extraordinary price of 96 cents per pound.
A party who purchased in the forenoon resold in the afternoon at a profit of $40 per bale.
At 96 cents per pound

div4.p:
fable of cotton is worth $482. Before the war it sold at 10 to 12 cents per pound, or at $45 in $54 per bale.
From present appearances it is possible that it may touch $1 per pound, or $450 per bale.
The present price is higher than it was before the invention of the cottongia and when the negroes at the South taked it with their fingers.

div4.head: The "Department of the South"
div4.p: Gen. Hunter, who has resumed the command of the "Department of the South, " has place Fargo Hilton Head, S. C, his general order is which the following plod paragraph course:

It is with sincere pleasure that the General Commanding returns to this Department-- the stray men of the North, whose destiny has been here cast, having never failed, although without many opportunities for great destruction to do their whole duty when called upon — as wilness Port Royal, Pulaski, James Island and Padatatigo --names to which every soldier of the command may look back with pride. Although not always successful-- a being depending on often beyond their --they have the freely equal merit of always having deserved success.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p: The Vanderbilt, the only ship that can catch the Alabama" sailed from Fortress Monroe Friday.
The Confederate privateer Retribution recently captured the brig J. P. Khicott, of Boston and put a prize crew aboard of her, who turned traitors, and her into St. Thomas.
Burnside spent Friday in visiting the New York public schools, making little addresses to the children and giving them his autograph.
The City Council of Boston has tendered McClellan the hospitalities of the city.
Governor Stanley, the "Military Governor" of North Caroline, has resigned.

Beast Butler had a long consultation with Lincoln and Stanton on Friday.
It is thought he will be returned to Louisiana.
Arrivals from the West Indies report the presence of a war steamer, which appears to be the Alabama, within about 300 miles of New York.
Gen. Franklin has demanded a Court of Inquiry into his conduct while in the Army of the Potomac.
Hon. Wm. A. Richardson, the new Senator, from Illinois, took his seat in the U. S. Senate on Friday.

The steamboat Glendale arrived at Evansville, Indiana, on the 26th inst., with one thousand and sixty bale of cotton from Memphis.
This is the largest cargo since the breaking out of the rebellion.

In the House of Representatives of Indiana, on the 27th inst., the joint resolution for a Convention of all the States at Louisville Ky., on the 4th of July next for the suspension of and for the adjustment of our national difficulties, was made the order of the day for the 15th of February.
As that date falls on Sunday, the movement was probably a trick of the radicals to kill the resolution.
Senator Saulsbury, of Delaware, has made a suitable apology to the U. S. Senate.

argument.p: the speech of Napoleon — Comments of the English Press upon it, &c., &c.

div4.p: The mails by the Saxonia, from Liverpool on the 14th ult., contain some intelligence of interest, of which we give a summary:

div4.head: France and America — address of Napoleon at the Opening of the Legislative Body.
div4.p: The session of the Senate and Corps Legislative was opened on the 12th by the Emperor, who delivered the following speech:

foreign.hi: Messieurs les Senatcurs, Messieurs les Deputies:

div4.p:
The Legislative Body is about to commence its last session.
To have anticipated the term fixed by the Constitution would have been, in my opinion, an act of ingratitude toward the Chamber, of mistrust toward the country.

The times have passed when it was thought necessary to take adventage of a happy incident to make sure of the votes of a restricted number of electors.
At the present day, when every one is aware that the masses no, longer possess the restlessness of former times convictions do not change at the slightest breath which seems to agitate the political atmosphere.

As we now most for the last time, it is advisable to cast a retrospective glance upon what we have done together during the last five years; for it in only by taking a connected view of a period of years that a correct at judgment can be formed of the consequent spirit with which the affairs of the country have been managed.

It is a usual thing to suspect in the acts of sovereigns some secret motive or some mysterious combination.
Yet; my policy has always been simply to increase the prosperity of France and her moral preponderance without abusing and without weakening the power placed in my hands; to maintain abroad within the limits of right and of treaties, the legitimate aspirations of nations toward a better position; to develop our commercial relations with those countries towards which we are drawn closer by a greater community of interests; to erase from diplomatic parchments the old questions of , so as to obviate all pretexts of misunderstanding; to insist finally, upon a full reparation for any insult offered to our flag, for any prejudice against our countrymen.
It is thus that, according to circumstances, I have been unabled to carry out these principles.

Our arms have defended the independence of Italy without tempering with revolution — without altering after the day of battle, our friendly relations with our adversaries even for a day — without abandoning the Holy Father, whom out honor and our past engagements bound us to support.
Commercial treaties have been or are on the eve of being concluded with England, Belgium, Frassia, Italy, and Switzerland.

Finally, expeditions to China, Cochin-China, and Mexico, prove that there are not any countries no matter how far distant, where any attempt against the honor of France remains unpunished.
Such facts could not be accomplished without complications.
Duty always advances through danger.--Nevertheless, France has been increased by two provinces.
The barriers which separated us from our neighbors have been removed; a vast territory has been thrown open to our activity in the far East; and, what is better than conquests, we have acquired claims to the sympathy of the inhabitants, without losing the confidence and the esteem of the Governments.

During the years recently passed I have been enabled to have personal interviews with most of the reigning sovereigns, and from those interviews friendly relations have arisen, which are so many guarantees for the peace of Europe.
The peace cannot be disturbed by the events which have just taken place in Greece.

This brief sketch of the past is a guarantee to you for the future, and despite the pressure of counteracting events and of opposing opinions, I hope that you will admit that I have always inflimeningly followed the same line of conduct.
As more particularly regards our position at home I have endeavored on the one hand, by a complete name by, to obliterate as far as I could, the remembrance of our civil discords, and, on the other hand, to increase the importance of the great bodies of the State.

I have called you to take a more direct part in the Government.
I have given to your deliberations all the guarantees which freedom of discussion could claim.
I have relinquished a prerogative, hither to deemed indispensable, so as to allow the legislative body to control the expenses in a more at solute manner, and to give more solidity to the bases upon which public credit rests.

To reduce our expenses, the army and navy estimates have been considerably diminished.
The floating debt has been reduced, and, by the success achieved by the conversion of the Pontes a great step has been taken toward the settlement (unification ) of that debt.
The indirect revenues snow a continual increase, from the simple fact of the general increase of prosperity, and the condition of the Empire would be flourishing if the war, in America had not dried up one of the most fruitful sources of our industry.
The forced stagnations of labor has caused in many districts an amount of destitution which destress all our solicitude and a grand will be asked from you for the support of those who with resignation submit to the effects of a misfortune which it is not in our poker to put a step to. Nevertheless I have made the attempt to send beyond the Atlantic advices inspired by a sincere sympathy; but the great maritime Powers not having thought it advisable as yet to act in concert with me I have been obliged to postpone to a move suitable opportunity the offer of mediation the object of which was to stop the effusion of blood and to prevent the exhaustion of a country the future of which cannot be looked upon with the difference.

div4.head: The Emperor Means renewed mediation.
div4.p: The London Times has the following editorial comment on the Emperor's speech:

As a politician and a soldier, Napoleon may be satisfied with the accuracy of his judgment when he declared that the South would not submit and could not be subjugated.
Since M. Drouya de LeHuys wrote his dispatch the fortune of war has more than over inclined to the side of the Confederates.
In a great battle they have defeated the main army of their enemies, and demonstrated that Virginia and Richmond, may be held indefinitely against all the hosts that President Lineans can send against them.
Such being the condition of the war, the French Emperor may justly ask whether Europe it to sit still and make no effort to save a civilized and Christian society from the miseries that are coming on it. The exhaustion of the country, and the of the people, are the only results which may be clearly if the war last; and the Emperor will do a good work if by any wise and advances he can persuade the Federal to from their hopeless enterprise.

div4.head: American Affairs.
div4.p:
The London Observer says:"Reports have been in circulation for some days past to the effect that the Emperor of the French had renewed his proposal of joint mediation between the contending parties in America.
We have to believe that no offer of the kind has been made to her Majesty's Government, and further, that the Emperor has distinctly intimated to Mr. Dayton, the American Minister at Paris that it is not his intention to submit any preposition for the settlement of the question in dispute between the Northern and Southern States.

A county meeting was held at on Saturday last, to raise funds for the relief of the Lancashire distress.
Lord Lyitle the Lord Lieutenant of the county, presided.
In moving a East Duty referred to the American war, and expressed his opinion that the time had some on the Southern States should be recognized as an independent nation.
In this opinion Mr. Lygon, M. P., Sir J. Packington urged the people on W not to imagine that the distress was away.
He believed it would continue for some time and he did not look for any early relief by the cotton from America.
The Moniteur, in its says: "A more decided movement in favor of peace is taking place in the United States"

The Swire Federal Assembly was opened January 12 In the Counted of the the President touched upon the apprehension that might be entertained for the future.
Without entering into particular of American affairs, the President expressed a hope that the Union would be able to maintain its vitality without foreign intervention, as was the case in Switzerland during the period of the

The official documents explaining the foreign policy of the French Government which were distributed among the Legislative Corps, say that distion in American affairs is postponed in consequence of the refusal of England and Russia to join France; but the Emperor has not from acquainting the Cabinet at Washington that his Government is still ready to mediate, provided the American Government France should alone or connectivity in which ever form may be pointed out to her.
The recall of Gen. Butler is regarded with sailed faction by a majority of the English journals and is considered hopeful, although not an act of grace.
The emancipation proclamation claimed the serious attention of the people, but was received too late for much newspaper comment before the sailing of the burg.
The Morning Post the death warrant of the United States and says it would be a terrible act if it could be enforced, but regards it wholly inoperative.
The Star that whatever be the immediate effect, the death knell of slavery.
The Telegraph says that the rancer and contempt of the South must be increased immensely, and if successful, never will military triumph have been purchased at

div3.head: Emeute in the City jail.
div3.p:
--There was a considerable emeute among the prisoners in the City Jail during Sunday night. After being looked up on that night they, by a preconcerted arrangement, commenced doing all the damage they could to the calls and other parts of the structure within reach, and by yesterday morning had succeeded in effecting considerable mischief, besides liberating a number of . When the jailor went yesterday morning to open the gate, as usual, they offered violent opposition, declaring that the first one who attempted the operation would be killed.
It was found necessary to call in the aid of the City Battalion, by whose assistance the ring-leaders were secured and bucked.
The jail is now, and has been a long time, filled to overflowing with an assortment of the grandest scamps in the Confederacy.

div3.head: Blockade goods.
div3.p:
--An instalment of Government goods, that had run the blockade, having arrived in Richmond a store was opened yesterday on 14th street, so that they could be disposed of to the soldiers at cost.
The vicinity was crowded during the day with army officers who happened to be in Richmond and took the opportunity of procuring cheap uniform cloth.

div3.head: The Abolition prisoners.
div3.p:
--A Yankee boat having reported her arrival at City Point, Gen. Winder will to-day send off by way of Petersburg, seven hundred and fifty of the Hessians captured by Gen. Bragg in Tennessee, this number being all that the boat has capacity to take away.
Some four or five hundred will still remain, who will be carried of the first available opportunity.

div3.head: For the Fredericksburg sufferers.
div3.p: --The members of the Chesapeake artillery, Capt. Wm. D. Brown--a company composed entirely of Marylanders — sent yesterday to Richmond $215, as a donation to the Fredericksburg sufferers.

div3.head: Military election.
div3.p: --At an election held on the 26th of January Major Jas. B. Herbert was elected Lieutenant Colonel of the 1st Maryland battalion of infantry.

div3.head: Court Proceedings.
div3.p: --James L. Nelson was charged with acting disorderly in the street while drunk, and was required to give security for his good behavior.
Million, slave of John Hutchinson, charged with throwing stones in the street, was proved guilty and ordered 15 lashes.
John Riley, charged with molesting people in the street while intoxicated, was required to give security for his good behavior, and failing was committed.
Thomas McBride, charged with getting drunk and effecting a forcible entrance into the barber shop of John Johnson, was required to give security for good behavior.

John A Johnson a lad, was charged with stealing a uniform from Wm. B. Wrenn.
The complainant not appearing on either of the days act apart for the examination, defendant was discharged from the criminal prosecution, but committed for want of security to be of good behavior.

Robert Lynne Wm. H. Manning, and George E. Verrell, were arraigned before the Mayor on the charge of feloniously obtaining $1,200 from Wm. A. Charters, a citizen of Richmond, on whom they had imposed a bogus substitute, who had been received into a bogus company.
The defendants, who are part of a regularly-organized band of swindling substitute agents, were arrested a few days ago by the detectives of the Provost of the Eastern District, and were sent before the Mayor from Castle Thunder.
The examination was continued until Tuesday.

div3.head: The Attack on the defences of Savannah.
div3.p:
--During the attach upon Fort McAllister this morning, the flag staff of the iron-clad was shot away.
She was anchored within one thousand yards of the Fort.
She retired evidently injured as she did not reply to shots from the Fort when retiring.
Though the front of one of the guns of the Fort was entirely demolished, the men remained firm.
There is no excitement, but the best spirits prevailed.

About 3 o'clock this afternoon an iron-clad and a gunboat approached within two miles of Thunderbelt battery, dipped a flag, fired two shots, and retired.
The Thunderbolt battery is five miles South of the city.

Two gunboats came up to St. Mary's on Monday inst.
One of them went up the river and act fire to the houses on several plantations.
Captain Harrison's company of cavalry fired on them, when they hauled off to a distance out of the range of small arms, and shelled furiously.
Another was landing men at St. Mary's on Tuesday.

div3.head: From Charleston.
div3.p:
--The British ship-Cadmus touched off Charleston Bar this afternoon.
One of her officers with a boat's crew came up to the city, passing the Yankee iron-clad New Ironside, which is lying in the office.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 29, page 2.

div3.head: Anti-slavery in England.
div3.p:
Because the London Times has ventured to suggest that slavery is not condemned by the Scriptures the vials of abolitionism in England have been uncorked upon its devoted head, and the Ezeter Hall organs predict that the announcement of such a godless proposition by the leading journal of the Kingdom will produce a universal reaction in that country against the Southern cause.
We have no apprehension that any such result will follow.
Even if the positions of the Times were unscriptural, the Southern cause could not be held responsible, by intelligent Englishmen, for the arguments of the Times. But at any dispassionate tribunal we should be perfectly willing to rest the whole Southern cause upon the propositions announced by the Times It is indeed, the mildest form of stating the Scriptural argument; for, not only does the Bible not condemn, but it explicitly unactions slavery.
The proofs of this have been presented to the American public in such a multitude of books, pamphlets, and speeches, that the merest child in the Confederacy could easily confound the ablest polemic of Exeter Hall upon the Scriptural view of the slavery question.

That the public sentiment of England should be shocked by the assertion that slavery is not condemned by Scripture, is a signal illustration of the power of fanaticism in blinding the mind to the clearest teachings of religious truth, and in substituting its own ignis fatuus light for the noonday insure of Divine Revolution.
It is the constant bo of Englishman that the Bible, and the Bible alone, is the religion of their country; but whenever the Bible comes in collision with the peculiar prejudices and dormer it is as completely ignored as the mythologies or the language of the Koran.
What renders still more astonishing the sensation that the proposition of the Times creates, is the fact that, not a century ago, every divine in Great Britain and every commentator upon Holy Witt taught precisely the same doctrine announced by the Times, and actually illustrating it by the same example, among others of the fugitive slave returned by St. Faul to his master.
For eighteen hundred years the universal Christian Church taught the doctrine, and not only this, but as a Church, as well as individually, owned slaves; and yet, at this late day the discovery is made by Exeter Hall that slavery is a sin, and that to say it is not is a "godless" declaration.
If that be so, then it has taken the Christian Church eighteen hundred years to find out what the Bible forbids, and the discovery has at last been made only by those whose interest it was to assume such a position.

In this connection, we observe that Bishop Rosecrans, of Cincinnati, (brother of Gen. Rosecrans,) has lately delivered a lecture in Ohio upon some old religious order for the ransom of slaves, which he is said to designate as the first anti-slavery society.
We take it for granted he refers to a Roman Catholic association which once existed for the ransom of Christian slaves from the Turks, and which ransomed them not only by paying for them, but sometimes by the members of the society actually taking the places of the captives in order to effect their liberation — Is that the kind of emancipation contemplated by the Gorilla and his Black Republicans?
We should be pleased to learn if Bishop Rosecrans instructed his Ohio hearers to go and do likewise?
Did he invoke his hearers to offer the full market value of the Southern slaves, and if that would not effect the object, to offer to become slaves themselves in place of the negroes?

div3.head: Married.
div3.p: On the 27th inst, by the Rev. Dr. Burrow, Mr. Wm. C. Graves, of Richmond, and Miss. Annie R. Pollard, of Charles City on, Va. *

div4.p: On the 1st last., of scarlet fever, Ella D. Jennings, aged 4 years and 3 months.

Her funeral will take place from the residence of Mr. J. D. Vaughan, in the county of Henrico, this day at 11 o'clock. The relatives and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend. *
On the 1st instant, Georgie Withers, only child of Josephine and the late George T. Wilson, aged 13 months and 8 days.
The friends of the family are invited to attend the funeral, this morning, at 11 o'clock, from the 1st Baptist Church.
Danville papers please copy. *

in Hanover county, on the 31st inst., after a painful illness, Ida B., daughter of Jas.
H. And Martha R. Bowles, aged 3 years and 10 days.

lg.l: Ida, again we hope to meet thee,
When the day of life has fled;
Then in Heaven with joy to great thee,
Where no farewell tear is shed.

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: Lieut. A. D. Doggett.--Tis with grief that we record the death of our beloved friend, Lieut. A. D. Doggett, Co. A, 53th Va. Reg't, who died from wounds received in the battle of Boonsboro', on the 14th of September, 1832.

Though he was a man of delicate health, he gallantly responded to his country's call, and has ever been foremost in danger.
No nobler or more generous heart than his has been sacrificed upon the altar of his country.
A tender and affectionate friend, his warm, social nature won the love of his comrades, not less than the cool intrepidity commanded their admiration in the hour of danger.--Notwithstanding the arduous duties of the camp, and the still more trying ones of the field, he found ample time and opportunity to form a circle of warm and loving friends, who deeply sympathize with his widowed mother and numerous friends.

lg.l: "How sleep the brave who sink to rest,
With all their country's wishes blest."

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--A young Woman, with her first child, about a year old. She is a good plain cook, washer, and ironer.
Apply at Mrs. Austin's, on 4th st, north of Broad st., cast side.

div3.head: Servant wanted.
div3.p:
--The undersigned wishes to hire a Woman, chiefly capable as a Washer and Ironer, and House Servant.
Apply at my office, on 13th street, or at my residence, on 10th, north of Leigh street.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--$25 Reward — Will be paid to any person who will notify the undersigned, through the Dispatch office, of a House which can be rented in a pleasant locality, containing six or eight rooms, furnished or unfurnished with out-houses.
The above reward is based upon immediate possession and terms to suit.

--Immediately, a first class Music Teacher, for a Seminary in Mississippi.
A very liberal salary is offered.
None but a really first-class teacher and performer need apply.
Apply to Prof Dr. CŒNiel, from 2 to 4 o'clock P M, corner of 1st and Grace streets, Richmond, Va

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--I am exempt from all military duty, and am desirous of getting a situation as Teacher.
Full particulars can be had by addressing "E. Dobber." Charlottesville, Va. immediately.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman who has a few hours of the day and night to spare, is desirous of obtaining a situation as Accountant Copyiel, or would keep a set of books, or clerk in any form.
Address "Francis," through Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A suitable Room to carry on the Currying and Finishing Business in, or I will take a room and Curry and Finish for any one engaged in cutting and working Leather — either Calf, Harness, or Russelt.
Apply at No. 75 Main street, Richmond.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --Spoke and are handle Billets, split and sawed Timber, of various kinds, for which the highest market price will be paid.--Call at Conant & Waldren's, on Cary street, opposite Ettenger & Edmond's

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A good front Room, on 1st or 2d floor, situated in the business part of the city.
For such an one a liberal rent will be paid, by addressing "J H H," Box 355, Richmond P O, care of J A Bill.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A young lady who has had some experience in Teaching desires to obtain a situation as Teacher in the country, either in a school or private family.
Salary no object for the present.
Address "Box 410," Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--Five respectable gentlemen can obtain Board by applying at Mrs. E. Richards's, on Franklin, between 17th and 18th streets, above the store of A Richards.
None but nice gentlemen need apply.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A white girl wishes a situation as Chambermaid and Seamstress in a private family.
Address "X," at this office.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--An experienced man, who thoroughly understands the defying of liquors.
None other need apply.
For such liberal wages will be paid.
Call at No. 8 Main street.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--an Overseer — I wish to employ a single man. For one that will suit I will hold out strong inducements.
Apply at the City Water Works.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--To rent, a small House, with three or four rooms, in a convenient neighborhood for getting up a school.
Apply to "S," Dispatch office

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A competent Miller, to attend a country mill.
Good references will be required.
Address Box 87, or apply at No. 150 Main street, Richmond.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Charcoal--520 bushels Charcoal wanted.
Apply to No. 8 Main st.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--An intelligent young Lady to assist in the store.
Best of reference required.
Apply to

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A young man from the country desires a situation in a commission house.
References given.
Address, "W," box 452.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A first-class Bugler.
Apply to
div3.closer:
T E Starks, Cpt and A Q M
25th Va Lat'n, Richmond. ja 23--6t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--the Highest price paid for a man over 45 and well recommended.
As he is wanted for a Conscript, he will have the choice of his company.
Call at Room No. 13, Columbian Hotel for three days.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--For a man over 45 years of age, and well recommended, a fair price will be paid.
Apply at the store of
div3.closer:
S. K. Owens & Son,
One door from Cary street. fe 3--3t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A reliable man over 45 years of age, can get a good price for going as substitute.
In a No. 1 cavalry company.
Inquire at

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Who can furnish satisfactory evidence as to age and character, for which a liberal price will be paid.
A native of one of the Southern States preferred.
Address "Box 754 " Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid for an acceptable substitute by a gentleman residing in Pittsylvania county, to serve in a first class cavalry company.
A good horse will be furnished.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Carlton, Chamberlain & Co,
No. 111 Main street. fe 2--4t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p: --For a man over 45 years old, well recommended, a liberal price will be paid.

Also, wanted to sell, several Houses and Lots and a fine, thorough bred Horse.
He rides and works well, and has been trained to cavalry service.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Dr. Broocks,
Corner of Main and 12th sts. ja 31--3t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--To serve in the 9th Regiment of Va. Cavalry.
To one over 45 years old a liberal price will be paid, and a horse and accoutrements will be furnished.
Apply at Mr. Wm. C. Allen's, corner of 6th and Franklin streets.

div3.head: Thirty-five likely Negroes.
div3.p: --On Wednesday, 4th February, at 10 o'clock, will be sold 35 likely, Negroes, consisting of Men, Boys, and Girls, amongst them are some good house servants and farm hands — belonging to one man.

Administrator's Sale of Eighty-Six Acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep Run Turnpike, at Auction.--As Administrator of John Ford, dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises on Saturday, the 14th day of February, 1833, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep-Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and as the Shepherd.
It contains 86 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several sooms.
Rarn, Stable, and other necessary out houses together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms--One-third cast; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust dred.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson.
Late Sheriff of Henrico co., and as such
Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas. H. Ford, who has failed to comply with the terms of sale.
J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 3

div3.p:
Administrator's Sale of 5,000 Cords of Fine Wood, 100,000 Febt.
Of Seasoned Lumber, and one Steam Saw Mill Will be sold to the highest bidder, on Thursday, the 12th day of February next, at the Saw Mill lately occupied by Rowland & Shriver, dec'd, about three miles from Cabin Point, Surry co., Va., the following property to wit:

1 Horse and Harness, 2 yoke of Oxen, I Steam Saw Mill and Fixtures, Wagons, Carts, Carrylogs; also, about 100,000 feet of seasoned Lumber, principally inch boards, and from five to seven thousand cords of Fine Wood, 5 Boole's cross out Saws, 1 pair large Patent Balances 50 bales of Nay and all the Fixtures, too numerous to mention, necessary to carry on a well kept Saw Mill.
Persons willing to purchase the wood columber, can have every facility for shipping to Richmond or Petersburg by the Norfolk and Petersburg Railroad, which is only a short distance.
Sale to commence at 11 o'clock A. M., when will be made known.

div3.head: Fifty Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ran away from my residence on the night of the 13th January, my house boy George.
The said boy is a bright mulatto, 5 feet 8 inches high.
He had on when he last a gray coat, gray pants, shoes that had been smartly worn, and gray cap. He is 12 years old, with fine set of teeth and full suit of black hair.--He has a little impediment in his speech when spoken to. He may be making his way to our army.
If caught in the county, I will pay $25; if caught out of the county and lodged in jail so that I get him again, I will pay $50.

closer.signed: Verdon P. O., Hanover county, Va.

div3.head: One hundred Dollars Reward.
div3.p: --Ranaway from the subscriber on the 1st day of February, a dark brown skin negro man, 6 feet high, named Peter, about 23 years old. I will give the above reward to any person who will bring him to me, or have him confined in any jail in the State that I may get him. He has a wife in Powhatan county, and was recently bought in Goochland county, Va.
div3.closer:
Daniel F. Ward.
Falls Plantation, Chesterfield county, Va. fe 3--2w

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--$100 Reward — I will give the above reward for the apprehension of my negro boy James, though sometimes called Jin Clarks.
He is very dark complected, low of stature, and very quick spoken and very polite when spoken to. He left the premises of Mr. G. A. W. Taylor on or about the 15th of February, 1862.
He has been seen in the city of Richmond during the last summer, and it is very likely be at this time in the employ of come of the of the Confederate Army.

closer.signed: Agent for J. R. W. Watkins

div3.head: Runaway or Stoles.
div3.p:
--Some time before Christmas my negro boy, John; supposed to have been, taken off by a Lieutenant of a Louisiana regiment.
He is a yellow boy, very stout, and about 14 or 15 years old. A reward of four hundred Dollars will be two hundred dollars for the boy, and two hundred for the Thief.
Address

div3.head: Fifty Dollars Reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Monday, Negro Woman, named Kitty, aged 49 years. Kitty is black of medium height, rather stout has lost a portion of her front teeth, and her eye teach projects so as to be quite noticeable.
Kitty was originally from the neighborhood of Looks Court-House, and may be attempting to make her way back.
She took with her several Liberty dresses and other articles of wearing apparel.
I will give the above reward for her arrest and confinement in jail so that I get her again.
